title: The Atomic Bomb Considered As Hungarian High School Science Fair Project
summary:
Key ideas:
- A group of physicists who worked on the Manhattan Project were Hungarian and were born in Budapest between 1890 and 1920.
- Many of these physicists attended the same high school or lived in the same general area.
- There were multiple high schools in Budapest that produced successful scientists and mathematicians during this time.
- There is a theory that Jewish people of Eastern European descent (Ashkenazi Jews) have a genetic advantage for higher IQ due to a history of persecution that pushed them into cognitively demanding jobs.
- Hungary had more Jews in the early 1900s than many other countries, and Budapest was one of the most Jewish cities anywhere in history.
- Central European Jews like those in Hungary and Germany had a unique combination of intellectual and financial advantages, which, along with social and economic factors, might explain why they produced so many genius physicists.
- The period from 1880 to 1920 was a window when the first generation of Jews were free to pursue their dreams.
- The story of the Martian phenomenon, which brought us some of the greatest progress in scientific history, is gloomy because it was then followed by World War II.

Key learnings:
- The success of these Hungarian physicists may have been influenced by a unique culture of education in Hungary at the time.
- Genetics may play a role in the high intelligence of Ashkenazi Jews, which has led to disproportionate representation in high IQ professions.
- The social and economic factors in a particular country at a particular time can influence the success of a group of people.
- In this case, the Ashkenazi Jews had the potential for high intelligence, but they were mostly too poor and discriminated against to take advantage of it until the conditions became ripe.
- The concentration of talent that existed in Central Europe during this period might have helped Jews and Gentiles alike.

Key questions:
- Was there something special about the education system in Hungary during this time period that contributed to the success of these physicists?
- Does genetics play a role in the high IQ of Ashkenazi Jews, and if so, why is this trait limited to only this ethnic group?
- Why did Hungary have more Jews than many other countries?
- Is there any reason to think that Central European Jews were more intelligent than Polish and Russian Jews?
- Was it better education or math competitions and talent searches that made Central European Jews excel in mathematics and physics?
